cluster_relations.rel_desc: The larval stage of a butterfly is realized as a caterpillar.
A caterpillar is the organismal form that constitutes the larval stage of a butterfly.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: when the butterfly is in its second life stage

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Biodiversity characterizes the ecosystem as a whole.
Adult butterflies represent the adult life stage of butterflies.
remarks: More of a conceptual mapping between the class 'adult butterflies' and the broader 'butterflies'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adult butterflies represent organisms in the adult butterfly life stage.

qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: implicit, not explicitly labeled as a stage in the text
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: LifespanContext: lifespan ranges from a few days to a few weeks depending on species

remarks: Relation added to connect the organism-level term with its life-stage abstraction.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a life stage concept to the characteristic organismal form that realizes that stage (e.g., the larval stage has organismal form caterpillar).
args.justification: The subject is an abstract life stage ('larval (caterpillar) stage of a butterfly') and the object is the organismal form ('caterpillar') that realizes that stage; this is best modeled as a life-stage-to-form mapping rather than a generic realization or classification relation.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links an organismal form to the life stage concept that it realizes (inverse of has_organismal_form).
args.justification: Here the subject is the organismal form ('caterpillar') and the object is the life stage abstraction ('larval (caterpillar) stage of a butterfly'); this is the inverse direction of the life-stage/organismal-form mapping and should be explicitly labeled as such.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a property or feature characterizes or is a defining attribute of a system or entity (e.g., biodiversity characterizes an ecosystem).
args.justification: The description states that biodiversity 'characterizes' the ecosystem, i.e., it is a defining property of the ecosystem; using a property-to-system predicate 'characterizes' captures this semantics more precisely than a generic association.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a group of organisms in a specific life stage to the broader taxon or species whose members they are (e.g., adult butterflies are the adult life-stage population of butterflies).
args.justification: The subject is 'adult butterflies' (a group in a specific life stage) and the object is 'butterflies' (the broader taxon); this is not just generic membership but specifically identifies that this population corresponds to a particular life stage of that taxon.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism or group of organisms is in a particular life stage (e.g., adult butterflies are in the adult butterfly stage).
args.justification: The subject is a group of organisms ('adult butterflies') and the object is a life stage abstraction ('adult butterfly stage'); this is best modeled as stage membership ('is in life stage') rather than a generic instance-of relation.

All four relations connect organisms, populations, or organismal forms to life stages or represent mappings between life stage abstractions and their realizations; grouping them under a common 'life_stage_relation' class captures this shared semantic family.

The relation links 'biodiversity' (a property) to 'ecosystem' (a system) in a way that expresses a defining attribute; this fits a class of relations where properties or qualities are attributed to systems or entities.

Life stages represent temporal phases in an organism's life cycle; relations specifying life-stage membership or mapping between a stage and its organismal form fundamentally concern temporal phases and therefore belong in the TEMPORALITY group.
The relation expresses that biodiversity is an attribute that characterizes an ecosystem; this is most naturally grouped as an ATTRIBUTE-type relation rather than composition or causality.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Links a life stage concept to the characteristic organismal form that realizes that stage (e.g., the larval stage has organismal form caterpillar).
executed_decisions.justification: The subject is an abstract life stage ('larval (caterpillar) stage of a butterfly') and the object is the organismal form ('caterpillar') that realizes that stage; this is best modeled as a life-stage-to-form mapping rather than a generic realization or classification relation.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Links an organismal form to the life stage concept that it realizes (inverse of has_organismal_form).
executed_decisions.justification: Here the subject is the organismal form ('caterpillar') and the object is the life stage abstraction ('larval (caterpillar) stage of a butterfly'); this is the inverse direction of the life-stage/organismal-form mapping and should be explicitly labeled as such.

executed_decisions.justification: The description states that biodiversity 'characterizes' the ecosystem, i.e., it is a defining property of the ecosystem; using a property-to-system predicate 'characterizes' captures this semantics more precisely than a generic association.

executed_decisions.justification: The subject is a group of organisms ('adult butterflies') and the object is a life stage abstraction ('adult butterfly stage'); this is best modeled as stage membership ('is in life stage') rather than a generic instance-of relation.

All four relations connect organisms, populations, or organismal forms to life stages or represent mappings between life stage abstractions and their realizations; grouping them under a common 'life_stage_relation' class captures this shared semantic family.

The relation links 'biodiversity' (a property) to 'ecosystem' (a system) in a way that expresses a defining attribute; this fits a class of relations where properties or qualities are attributed to systems or entities.

Life stages represent temporal phases in an organism's life cycle; relations specifying life-stage membership or mapping between a stage and its organismal form fundamentally concern temporal phases and therefore belong in the TEMPORALITY group.
The relation expresses that biodiversity is an attribute that characterizes an ecosystem; this is most naturally grouped as an ATTRIBUTE-type relation rather than composition or causality.
